objectives: Apply learned skills in various real-life scenarios
Practice confident English speaking in different situations
Work effectively in groups using English

sections.text: In previous lessons, you learned how to buy vegetables, ask for directions, and talk to a doctor. Now, we will put all these skills together. Real-life conversations often mix different topics. This lesson will help you use all your learned English words and sentences in bigger, real-world situations. It's like building a complete house using all the bricks you learned to make.

sections.text: Speaking a new language can be a little scary, but practice makes it easy. Confidence means believing in yourself. Don't be afraid to make mistakes, as everyone makes them when learning. The more you speak, the more confident you will become. Think of your English like a muscle; the more you use it, the stronger it gets. Try to speak without fear. Just open your mouth and try your best.

sections.text: Imagine you are a parent or guardian wanting to admit a child to a new school. You will need to ask questions about the school, admission process, fees, and other details. This involves polite inquiry and understanding information.
usage_examples:
Parent: Good morning, sir. I would like to inquire about school admission.
Clerk: Good morning. For which class are you looking for admission?
Parent: For Class 6. What is the admission process?
Clerk: First, you need to fill an application form. Then there will be a small test for the child.
Parent: What are the school fees per month?
Clerk: The fee is 500 rupees per month.
Parent: What documents are required for admission?
Clerk: You need the child's birth certificate, Aadhaar card, and previous school report card.
Parent: When can we visit the school to see the classrooms?
Clerk: You can visit tomorrow between 10 AM and 12 PM.
Parent: Thank you very much for the information.
Clerk: You're welcome. We look forward to seeing you.
Parent: Are there any extra charges for books?
Clerk: Yes, books and uniform fees are separate.
Parent: Is there a bus facility for students from our village?
Clerk: Yes, the school bus comes to your village.

sections.text: Imagine you have lost something important, like your school bag or a book, in the school or village. You need to report it to someone, like a teacher or a village elder. You have to clearly describe what you lost and when/where you last saw it.
usage_examples:
Student: Excuse me, sir. I need to report a lost item.
Teacher: Yes, what did you lose?
Student: I lost my school bag. It's a blue bag with my name on it.
Teacher: When and where did you last see it?
Student: I think I left it in the playground during lunch break today.
Teacher: What was inside the bag?
Student: My notebooks, a pen box, and my lunch box.
Teacher: Don't worry. We will make an announcement. What is your name and class?
Student: My name is Suresh, Class 7.
Teacher: Okay, Suresh. We will let you know if we find it.
Student: Thank you very much, sir.
Teacher: You're welcome. We hope to find it soon.
Student: Does it have a special mark?
Teacher: No, it's just a plain blue bag.
Student: I hope someone finds it and returns it.

sections.text: Imagine you have guests visiting your home, maybe from the city or another village. You need to introduce them to your family members and also introduce your family members to the guests. This needs polite and clear introduction phrases.
usage_examples:
You: Welcome, Uncle and Auntie! It's so good to see you.
Guest: Thank you, dear. It's lovely to be here.
You: Papa, this is my Uncle Ramesh and Auntie Shanti from the city.
Father: Welcome, welcome. Please come in.
You: Uncle, Auntie, this is my father. And this is my mother.
Guest: Namaste, it's a pleasure to meet you both.
Mother: Please make yourself comfortable. Would you like some water?
You: And this is my younger sister, Geeta. Geeta, say hello to Uncle and Auntie.
Sister: Hello, Uncle. Hello, Auntie.
You: This is my cousin, Rahul. He has come from another village.
Guest: Nice to meet you, Rahul.
You: This is my grandmother, she is the oldest in our family.
Guest: Namaste, Mataji.
You: This is our neighbour, Mr. Sharma, he always helps us.
Guest: Hello, Mr. Sharma. Nice to meet you.

sections.text: Imagine some tourists or visitors come to your village. They might need help finding places like a temple, a specific shop, or asking about local customs. You need to use your English to help them with directions and information about your village.
usage_examples:
Tourist: Excuse me, can you tell me where the old temple is?
You: Yes, sir. Go straight from here, and turn left at the big banyan tree. The temple will be on your right side.
Tourist: Is it far from here?
You: No, sir. It's about a five-minute walk.
Tourist: Thank you. And is there a place to buy local handicrafts?
You: Yes, there's a small shop near the main market. You can find many handmade items there.
Tourist: How do I get to the market?
You: Continue straight after the temple, and the market will be on your left, after the school.
Tourist: Great, thank you for your help.
You: You're welcome, sir. Enjoy your visit to our village.
Tourist: What is special about this temple?
You: It is very old and famous for its yearly festival.
Tourist: Is there a good place to eat local food?
You: Yes, near the market, there are small food stalls with tasty local dishes.
Tourist: Are these vegetables grown in your village?
You: Yes, madam. Most of them are fresh from our village farms.

subtopics.title: Task 1: Planning a Village Clean-up Drive

sections.text: Work in groups. Imagine your class wants to organize a clean-up drive in your village. Discuss how you will plan it. Talk about the date, who will gather tools, who will make announcements, and which areas to clean. Use English to discuss and decide together.
usage_examples:
Student A: Let's plan our village clean-up drive. When should we do it?
Student B: How about next Saturday morning?
Student C: That sounds good. Who will gather brooms and dustpans?
Student A: I will be responsible for gathering the tools from homes.
Student B: We need to make an announcement in the village. Who will do that?
Student C: I can talk to the village head and ask him to announce it in the temple.
Student A: Which areas should we clean first?
Student B: Let's start with the market area and then the area around the pond.
Student C: We will need more volunteers for this. Who will ask other students to join?
Student A: I will talk to the students from Class 9 and 10.
Student B: We should also arrange for some drinking water for everyone.
Student C: Yes, I will ask my mother to help with that.
Student A: So, we are all clear on our tasks?
Student B: Yes, let's work together for a clean village.
Student C: This will be a great effort.

subtopics.title: Task 2: Organizing a Book Reading Session

sections.text: Your group decides to organize a book reading session for younger students in your school. Discuss how you will organize it. What books will you choose? Who will read? Where will it happen? When will it happen?
usage_examples:
Student A: Let's organize a book reading session for younger kids.
Student B: Great idea! What kind of books should we choose?
Student C: We should choose simple storybooks with many pictures.
Student A: Who will read the stories?
Student B: I can read one story, and Rohan can read another.
Student C: Where should we hold the session? In the library or outside?
Student A: The library is better, it's quiet.
Student B: When will we do it? After school on Tuesday?
Student C: Yes, Tuesday after school sounds good. We will inform the younger students.
Student A: We also need to arrange mats for them to sit on.
Student B: I will talk to the librarian about the mats.
Student C: We will make sure it's a fun and educational session.
Student A: Will we need any props for the stories?
Student B: Maybe some small puppets for a story.
Student C: We will discuss that more tomorrow.

sections.text: Your group's task is to create a small newsletter for your school. Discuss what sections it will have, who will write what, and how you will print it. Use English for all your discussions.
usage_examples:
Student A: We need to create a school newsletter. What should we include?
Student B: How about a section on recent school events?
Student C: And a section for student art and poems.
Student A: Who will write about the school events?
Student B: I can write about the Sports Day, and you can write about the Annual Function.
Student C: Who will collect the student art and poems?
Student A: Meena and Sita can do that.
Student B: How will we print the newsletter?
Student C: We will ask the Principal for permission to use the school printer.
Student A: What will be the name of our newsletter?
Student B: 'The School Voice' sounds good.
Student C: We will try to publish it every month.
Student A: Who will edit the content?
Student B: Our English teacher can help us with editing.
Student C: This will be a great way to share news.

sections.text: The English you learn in these lessons is for daily use. Try to use it in your real life, even in small ways. Speak English with your friends, family, or teachers. Think of situations where you can use the words and phrases you learned. The more you use English outside the classroom, the faster you will learn and become comfortable with it.
